unnormalised: Someone asked me about time differences in India. So, India follows Indian Standard Time (IST), which is GMT+5:30. This means if it's 12:00 PM in London (GMT), it's 5:30 PM in India. Pretty straightforward, right? However, there are some interesting aspects to consider. For instance, Arunachal Pradesh, being the easternmost state, sees sunrise almost 2 hours before Gujarat, but the entire country operates on the same IST. There was talk of implementing a separate time zone for the northeast to improve efficiency, but that's still under debate.
normalised: Someone asked me about time differences in India. So, India follows Indian Standard Time (I-S-T), which is G-M-T plus five hours thirty minutes. This means if it's twelve P-M in London (G-M-T), it's five thirty P-M in India. Pretty straightforward, right? However, there are some interesting aspects to consider. For instance, Arunachal Pradesh, being the easternmost state, sees sunrise almost two hours before Gujarat, but the entire country operates on the same I-S-T. There was talk of implementing a separate time zone for the northeast to improve efficiency, but that's still under debate.

unnormalised: Now, let's say you're planning a conference call between Mumbai and New York. New York follows Eastern Time (ET), which is usually GMT-5. But remember Daylight Saving Time (DST)! From March to November, they observe EDT, which is GMT-4. So, the time difference can vary. For example, in July, when New York is on EDT, a 10:00 AM meeting in New York would be 7:30 PM IST. It gets a bit tricky, so always double-check the DST status before scheduling!
normalised: Now, let's say you're planning a conference call between Mumbai and New York. New York follows Eastern Time (E-T), which is usually G-M-T minus five. But remember Daylight Saving Time (D-S-T)! From March to November, they observe E-D-T, which is G-M-T minus four. So, the time difference can vary. For example, in July, when New York is on E-D-T, a ten A-M meeting in New York would be seven thirty P-M I-S-T. It gets a bit tricky, so always double-check the D-S-T status before scheduling!

unnormalised: Also, keep in mind that some neighboring countries have different time zones. Pakistan is GMT+5, Bangladesh is GMT+6, and Sri Lanka is also GMT+5:30 like India. So, if you're coordinating with colleagues across South Asia, you'll need to factor in those differences too. Using a time zone converter is your best bet to avoid any confusion. Websites like TimeAndDate.com or even a simple Google search ("10 AM in New York to IST") can save you from scheduling mishaps.
